Description: Fine scarab, made of glazed steatite, completely preserved. Remains of white glaze preserved on parts of the back and plate, the steatite is beige. The division between head and prothorax is shown with a single line. The division between prothorax and elytra is shown in a very thin line as is the suture. The humeral callosities are indicated by a small carved triangle, the outer part of the elytra is lined with a double line at the side and a single line at the bottom. On the right elytrum a mAa.t-feather is incised. The shape of the head is oval, with small round eyes at each side. The clypeus shows remains of three grooves, dividing it into four lobes, but the frontal part is chipped off. The plates at the sides are shown as well. The side of the scarab shows three finely carved legs on each side that show details of hairs in small grooves on all legs. Seen from the side, the legs are sitting on a base plate. The seal at the base shows an oval line framing the base, inside several hieroglyphs. From top to bottom: Mn-kheper-Ra tjt (D17) nb kpS Re mry-'Imn The orientation of the seal is longitudinal, as is the perforation of the object.
Bibliographic references: Spencer 1997 / Amara West I, The Architectural Report (p. 24)
